intro: Hibiscus coulteri var. brevipedunculatus, commonly known as the short-stalked sandverbena, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, characterized by its showy, pentagonal flowers that typically bloom in shades of pink to red. The plant has hairy, lance-shaped leaves and produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small, round seeds. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in arid or semi-arid environments. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
